Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Production and Perception of F0: An Experimental Analysis of Norwegian Tonal Accent

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This dissertation examines the interaction among lexical, sentence-level and pragmatic factors in determining pitch variation in the Trøndelag variety of Norwegian. Scandinavian languages, including the Trøndelag variety, are characterized by a lexical pitch accent contrast (accent 1 vs. accent 2). The accent distinction refers to a specified pitch contour on stressed syllables which changes the meaning of words. The shape of these contours varies across dialects. The pitch contours are further affected by pragmatic and prosodic factors. The goal of this research is to explore the interaction of these factors in determining pitch variation from the perspective of both production and perception.

Under the direction of Dr. Smiljanic, Niamh Kelly will carry out a set of production experiments to determine which acoustic-articulatory cues are systematically produced to distinguish the two accents in the dialect and how they are modified by sentential intonation and pragmatic focus. Perception studies will examine which acoustic cues are used by listeners to distinguish between the lexical pitch contrast and how pitch variation due to pragmatic and prosodic factors further shapes listeners' responses.

This project will advance our knowledge of phonetic features of lexical pitch accent distinctions (production) and of of phonetic cuing of these distinctions (perception). The findings will provide insights into phonological questions regarding the nature of the underlying representation of pitch accent contrasts and of tone bearing units. This award will enhance the training and research experience of a female graduate student.

Performance_Institution.Name: The University of Texas at Austin

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has provided an acoustic description of the lexical tonal accent in both monosyllabic and disyllabic words in the Trøndersk variety of Norwegian.

Production experiments with ten speakers allowed for a detailed acoustic analysis of this intonational feature, providing an in-depth description of the tonal contours of accent 1 and accent 2 words in disyllabic words. Furthermore, the monosyllabic contrast was analyzed, and found to still have consistent acoustic correlates even though it is thought to be disappearing. The results showed a high-low contour for both disyllabic accents, with accent 2 being differentiated from accent 1 by a higher f0 minimum and a later timing in relation to the segmental string. In the monosyllabic contrast, the circumflex accent was found to have a high-low contour and the unmarked accent simply a low tone contour.

The accents were also examined under narrow focus, and it was found that for both disyllabic and monosyllabic words, differences between the accents were enhanced in narrow focus. Furthermore, accent 1 had an expanded pitch range and accent 2 an even later timing, in narrow focus. In monosyllabic words, timing of both accents was later in narrow focus.

Perception experiments involving manipulated versions of the disyllabic accents provided further information on what acoustic cues listeners use to distinguish the accents. In line with the production results, it was found that a higher and later f0 minimum induced more accent 2 responses, as did a later f0 maximum timing and a later timing of the turning point for the f0 maximum to the f0 minimum. These results corroborated the description of the accents as being differentiated by timing.

This project has contributed to the literature on Scandinavian accent and to the literature on how higher level intonation, such as pragmatic focus, interacts with lexical pitch. The results have been presented at a number of international conferences and are currently under review in a number of journals.


Last Modified: 09/10/2015
Modified by: Niamh Kelly

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project has provided an acoustic description of the lexical tonal accent in both monosyllabic and disyllabic words in the Trøndersk variety of Norwegian. Production experiments with ten speakers allowed for a detailed acoustic analysis of this intonational feature, providing an in-depth description of the tonal contours of accent 1 and accent 2 words in disyllabic words. Furthermore, the monosyllabic contrast was analyzed, and found to still have consistent acoustic correlates even though it is thought to be disappearing. The results showed a high-low contour for both disyllabic accents, with accent 2 being differentiated from accent 1 by a higher f0 minimum and a later timing in relation to the segmental string. In the monosyllabic contrast, the circumflex accent was found to have a high-low contour and the unmarked accent simply a low tone contour. The accents were also examined under narrow focus, and it was found that for both disyllabic and monosyllabic words, differences between the accents were enhanced in narrow focus. Furthermore, accent 1 had an expanded pitch range and accent 2 an even later timing, in narrow focus. In monosyllabic words, timing of both accents was later in narrow focus. Perception experiments involving manipulated versions of the disyllabic accents provided further information on what acoustic cues listeners use to distinguish the accents. In line with the production results, it was found that a higher and later f0 minimum induced more accent 2 responses, as did a later f0 maximum timing and a later timing of the turning point for the f0 maximum to the f0 minimum. These results corroborated the description of the accents as being differentiated by timing. This project has contributed to the literature on Scandinavian accent and to the literature on how higher level intonation, such as pragmatic focus, interacts with lexical pitch. The results have been presented at a number of international conferences and are currently under review in a number of journals. Last Modified: 09/10/2015 Submitted by: Niamh Kelly
